item.title: Bulk Downloading Adobe Analytics Data
item.description: This blog post also serves as release notes for RSiteCatalyst v1.4.9, as only one feature was added (batch report request and download). But it‚Äôs a feature big enough for its own post!

item.title: Adobe Analytics Clickstream Data Feed: Calculations and Outlier Analysis
item.description: In a previous post, I outlined how to load daily Adobe Analytics Clickstream data feeds into a PostgreSQL database. While this isn‚Äôt a long-term scalable solution for large e-commerce companies doing millions of page views per day, for exploratory analysis a relational database structure can work well until a more robust solution is put into place (such as Hadoop/Spark).

item.title: Adobe: Give Credit. You DID NOT Write RSiteCatalyst.
item.description: EDIT 5/10/2016 1:30pm: Several folks from Adobe Analytics/Adobe Marketing Cloud have contacted me, and everything is resolved. I can‚Äôt untweet other people‚Äôs retweets/shares or delete comments on LinkedIn, but if everyone could stop sharing any more that would be great. üôÇ

No output has been received in the last 10m0s, this potentially indicates a 
stalled build or something wrong with the build itself.

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4.8 Release Notes
item.description: For being in RSiteCatalyst retirement, I‚Äôm ending up working on¬†more functionality lately¬†¬Ø_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø. Here are the changes for RSiteCatalyst 1.4.8, which should be available on CRAN shortly:

item.title: Adobe Analytics Clickstream Data Feed: Loading To Relational Database
item.description: In my previous post about the Adobe Analytics Clickstream Data Feed, I showed how it was possible to take a single day worth of data and build a dataframe in R. However, most likely your analysis will require using multiple days/weeks/months of data, and given the size and complexity of the feed, loading the files into a relational database makes a lot of sense. Although there may be database-specific ‚Äúfast-load‚Äù tools more appropriate for this application, this blog post will show how to handle this process using only R and PostgresSQL.

item.description: It‚Äôs only been a month¬†since the last RSiteCatalyst update, and this update is also a pretty minor update in terms of functionality.

item.title: JuliaCon 2015: Everyday Analytics and Visualization (video)
item.description: At long last, here‚Äôs the video of my presentation from JuliaCon 2015, discussion common analytics tasks and visualization. This is really two talks, the first being an example of using the citibike NYC API to analyze ridership of their public bike program, and the second a discussion of the Vega.jl package.

item.title: Apple MacBook Pro Model A1286 Declared Vintage – The End Of An Era
item.description: It‚Äôs hard to believe it‚Äôs been over 2.5 years since I wrote about my experience with Apple trying to get my¬†Broken MacBook Pro Hinge¬†fixed. Since that time, my Late 2008 MacBook Pro continued to work flawlessly, most of the time keeping up with the scientific programming I would do in R, Python or Julia.

item.title: Authenticated API Testing Using Travis CI
item.description: As I‚Äôve become more serious about contributing in the open-source community, having quality tests for my packages has been something I‚Äôve spent much more time on than when I was¬†just¬†writing quick-and-dirty code for¬†my own purposes. My most used open-sourced package is RSiteCatalyst, which accesses the Adobe Analytics (authenticated) API, which poses a problem: how do you maintain a project on GitHub with a full test suite, while at the same time not hard-coding your credentials in plain sight for everyone to see?

item.title: Getting Started: Adobe Analytics Clickstream Data Feed
item.description: ‚ÄúWell, first you need a TMS and a three-tiered data layer, then some jQuery with a node backend to inject customer data into the page asynchronously if you want to avoid cookie-based limitations with cross-domain tracking and be Internet Explorer 4 compatible‚Ä¶‚Äù

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4.4 Release Notes
item.description: It‚Äôs been about six months since the last RSiteCatalyst update, and this update is really just a single bug fix, but a big bug fix at that!

item.title: Vega.jl Rebooted – Now with 100% More Pie and Donut Charts!
Sessionizing Log Data Using data.table [Follow-up #2]
item.description: Thanks to user¬†dnlbrky, we now have a third way to accomplish sessionizing log data for any arbitrary time out period (see methods 1 and 2), this time using data.table from R along with magrittr for piping:

item.title: Sessionizing Log Data Using dplyr [Follow-up]
item.description: Last week, I wrote a blog post showing how to sessionize log data using standard SQL. The main idea of that post is that if your analytics platform supports¬†window functions (like Postgres and Hive do), you can make quick work out of sessionizing logs. Here‚Äôs the winning query:One nested sub-query and two window functions are all it takes to calculate the event boundaries and create a unique identifier for sessions for any arbitrary timeout chosen.

item.title: Sessionizing Log Data Using SQL
item.description: Over my career as a predictive modeler/data scientist, the most important step(s) in any data project without question have been data cleaning and feature engineering. By taking the data you have, correcting flaws and reformulating raw data into additional¬†business-specific concepts, you ensure that you move beyond pure mathematical optimization and actually solve a business problem.¬†While ‚Äúbig data‚Äù is often held up as¬†the future of knowing everything, when it comes down to it, a Hadoop cluster is more often a ‚ÄúHa-dump‚Äù cluster: the place data gets dumped without any proper ETL.

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4.3 Release Notes
item.description: It‚Äôs a new year, so‚Ä¶new version of RSiteCatalyst on CRAN! For the most part, this release fixes a handful of bugs that weren‚Äôt noticed with the prior release 1.4.2 (oops!), but there are pieces of additional functionality.

item.title: Review: Data Science at the Command Line
item.description: Admission: I didn‚Äôt really know how computers worked until around 2012.

item.title: Introducing Twitter.jl
item.description: This is possibly the latest ‚Äúannouncement‚Äù of a package ever, given that Twitter.jl has actually existed on METADATA for nearly a year now, but that‚Äôs how things go sometimes. Here‚Äôs how to get started with Twitter.jl and some of the highlights.

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4.2 Release Notes
item.description: RSiteCatalyst version 1.4.2 is now available on CRAN. This update was primarily bug fixes with one additional feature added.

item.title: Destroy Your Data Using Excel With This One Weird Trick!
item.description: All you pie-chart haters are wishing I used one here.

item.title: Code Refactoring Using Metaprogramming
item.description: It‚Äôs been nearly a year since I wrote¬†Twitter.jl, back when I seemingly had MUCH more free time.¬†In these past 10 months, I‚Äôve used Julia quite a bit to develop other packages, and I try to use it at work when I know I‚Äôm not going to be collaborating with others (since my colleagues don‚Äôt know Julia, not because it‚Äôs bad for collaboration!).

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4.1 Release Notes

item.description:
Is Twitter bankruptcy a thing? Delete all the people you follow and force yourself to re-discover them again?

item.title: Evaluating BreakoutDetection
item.description: A couple of weeks ago, Twitter open-sourced their BreakoutDetection package for R, a package designed to determine shifts in time-series data. The Twitter announcement does a great job of explaining the main technique for detection (E-Divisive with Medians), so I won‚Äôt rehash that material here. Rather, I wanted to see how this package works relative to the anomaly detection feature in the Adobe Analytics API, which I‚Äôve written about previously.

item.title: Visualizing Website Pathing With Sankey Charts
item.description: In my prior post on visualizing website structure using network graphs, I referenced that network graphs showed the pairwise relationships between two pages (in a bi-directional manner). However, if you want to analyze how your visitors are pathing through your site, you can visualize your data using a Sankey chart.

item.title: Creating A Stacked Bar Chart in Seaborn
item.description: The other day I was having a heck of a time trying to figure out how to make a stacked bar chart in Seaborn. But in true open-source/community fashion, I ended up getting a response from the creator of Seaborn via Twitter:

item.title: Visualizing Website Structure With Network Graphs
item.description: Last week, version 1.4 of RSiteCatalyst was released, and now it‚Äôs possible to get site pathing information directly within R. Now, it‚Äôs easy to create impressive looking network graphs from your Adobe Analytics data using¬†RSiteCatalyst and¬†d3Network. In this blog post, I will cover simple and force-directed network graphs, which show the pairwise representation between pages. In a follow-up blog post, I will show how to visualize longer paths using Sankey diagrams, also from the d3Network package.

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.4 Release Notes
item.description: It felt like it would never happen, but RSiteCatalyst v1.4 is now available on CRAN! There are numerous changes in this version of the package, so unlike previous posts, there won‚Äôt be any code examples.

item.title: Visualizing Analytics Languages With VennEuler.jl
item.description: It often doesn‚Äôt take much to get me off track, and on a holiday weekend‚Ä¶well, I was just begging for a fun way to shirk. Enter Harlan Harris:

item.title: String Interpolation for Fun and Profit
item.description: In a¬†previous post, I showed how I frequently use Julia as a ‚Äòglue‚Äô language to connect multiple systems in a complicated data pipeline. For this blog post, I will show two more examples where I use Julia for general programming, rather than for computationally-intense programs.

item.title: Maybe I Don’t Really Know R After All
item.description: Lately, I‚Äôve been feeling that I‚Äôm spreading myself too thin in terms of programming languages. At work, I spend most of my time in Hive/SQL, with the occasional Python for my smaller data. I really prefer Julia, but I‚Äôm alone at work on that one. And since¬†I maintain a package on CRAN (RSiteCatalyst), I frequently¬†spend my evenings¬†bug fix programming in R. Then, there‚Äôs the desire to learn a Java-based language like Scala (or, Java)‚Ä¶maybe Spark for my Hadoop work‚Ä¶

item.title: Using Julia As A ‘Glue’ Language
item.description: While much of the focus in the Julia community has been on the performance aspects of Julia relative to other scientific computing languages, Julia is also perfectly suited to ‚Äòglue‚Äô together multiple data sources/languages. In this blog post, I will cover how to create an interactive plot using Gadfly.jl, by first preparing the data using Hadoop and Teradata Aster via ODBC.jl.

item.title: Five Hard-Won Lessons Using Hive
item.description: I‚Äôve been spending a ton of time lately on the data engineering side of ‚Äòdata science‚Äô, so I‚Äôve been writing a lot of Hive queries. Hive is a great tool for querying large amounts of data, without having to know very much about the underpinnings of Hadoop. Unfortunately, there are a lot of things about Hive (version 0.12 and before) that aren‚Äôt quite the same as SQL and have caused me a bunch of frustration; here they are, in no particular order.

item.title: Building JSON in R: Three Methods
item.description: When I set out to build RSiteCatalyst, I had a few major goals: learn R, build a CRAN-worthy package and learn the Adobe Analytics API. As I reflect back on how the package has evolved over the past two years and what I‚Äôve learned, I think my greatest learning was around¬†how to deal with JSON (and strings in general). ¬†JSON is ubiquitous as a data-transfer mechanism over the web, and R does a decent job providing the functionality to not only read JSON but also to create JSON. There are at least three methods I know of to build JSON strings, and this post will cover the pros and cons of each method.

item.title: Using SQL Workbench with Apache Hive
item.description: If you‚Äôve spent any non-trivial amount of time working with Hadoop and Hive at the command line, you‚Äôve likely wished that you could interact with¬†Hadoop like you would any other database. If you‚Äôre lucky, your Hadoop administrator has already installed the Apache Hue front-end to your cluster, which allows for interacting with Hadoop via an easy-to-use browser interface. However, if you don‚Äôt have Hue, Hive also supports access via JDBC; the downside is, setup is not as easy as including a single JDBC driver.

item.title: Real-time Reporting with the Adobe Analytics API
item.description: Starting with version 1.3.1 of RSiteCatalyst, you can now access the real-time reporting capabilities of the Adobe Analytics API¬†through a familiar R interface. Here‚Äôs how to get started‚Ä¶

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.3 Release Notes
item.description: Version 1.3 of the RSiteCatalyst package to access the Adobe Analytics API is now available on CRAN! Changes include:

item.title: Getting Started With Hadoop, Final: Analysis Using Hive & Pig
item.description: We‚Äôve finally made it to the final post in this tutorial! In my prior posts about getting started with Hadoop, we‚Äôve covered the entire lifecycle from how to set up a small cluster using Amazon EC2 and Cloudera through how to load data using Hue. With our data loaded in HDFS, we can finally move on to the actual analysis portion of the airline dataset using Hive and Pig.

item.title: Quickly Create Dummy Variables in a Data Frame
item.description: On Quora, a question was asked about how to fix the error of the randomForest package in R not being able to handle more than 32 levels in a categorical variable. Seeing as how I‚Äôve seen this question asked on Kaggle forums, StackOverflow and elsewhere, here‚Äôs the answer: code your own dummy variables instead of relying on Factors!

item.title: Adobe Analytics Implementation Documentation in 60 Seconds
item.description: When I was working as a digital analytics consultant, no question quite had the ability to cause belly laughs AND angst as, ‚ÄúCan you send me an updated copy of your implementation documentation?‚Äù I saw companies that were spending six-or-seven-figures annually on their analytics infrastructure, multi-millions in salary for employees and yet the only way to understand what data they were collecting was to inspect their JavaScript code.

item.title: Using Amazon EC2 with IPython Notebook
item.description: Last week, I wrote a guest blog post at Bad Hessian about how to use IPython Notebook along with Amazon EC2 as your data science & analytics platform. I won‚Äôt reproduce the whole article here, but if you are interested in step-by-step instruction on how to setup an Amazon EC2 instance to use IPython Notebook, see the SlideShare presentation below which outlines the steps needed to setup a remote IPython Notebook environment (or, PDF download).

item.title: Adding Line Numbers in IPython/Jupyter Notebooks
item.description: Lately, I‚Äôve been using Jupyter¬†Notebooks for all of my Python and Julia coding. The ability to develop and submit small snippets of code and create plots inline is just so useful that it has broken the stranglehold of using an IDE while I‚Äôm coding. However, the one thing that was missing for a smooth transition was line numbers in the cells; luckily, this can be achieved in two ways.

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.2 Release Notes
item.description: Version 1.2 of the¬†RSiteCatalyst¬†package to access the Adobe Analytics API¬†is now available on CRAN! Changes include:

item.title: Clustering Search Keywords Using K-Means Clustering
item.description: One of the key tenets to doing impactful digital analysis is understanding what your visitors are trying to accomplish. One of the easiest methods to do this is by analyzing the words your visitors use to arrive on site (search keywords) and what words they are using while on the site (on-site search).¬†Although Google has made it much more difficult to analyze search keywords over the past several years (due to their passing of ‚Äú(not provided)‚Äù instead of the actual keywords), we can create customer intent segments based on the keywords that are still being passed using unsupervised clustering methods such as k-means clustering.

item.title: Fun With Just-In-Time Compiling: Julia, Python, R and pqR
item.description: Recently I‚Äôve been spending a lot of time trying to learn Julia by doing the problems at Project Euler. What‚Äôs great about these problems is that it gets me out of my normal design patterns, since I don‚Äôt generally think about prime numbers, factorials and other number theory problems during my normal workday. These problems have also given me the opportunity to really think about how computers work, since Julia allows the programmer to pass type declarations to the just-in-time compiler (JIT).

item.title: RSiteCatalyst Version 1.1 Release Notes
item.description: RSiteCatalyst version 1.1 is now available on CRAN. Changes from version 1 include:

item.title: Getting Started Using Hadoop, Part 4: Creating Tables With Hive
item.description: In the previous three tutorials (1, 2, 3), we‚Äôve covered the background of Hadoop, how to build a proof-of-concept Hadoop cluster using Amazon EC2 and how to upload a .zip file to the cluster using Hue. In Part 4, we‚Äôll use the data uploaded from the .zip file to create a master table of all files, as well as creating a view.

item.title: Anomaly Detection Using The Adobe Analytics API
Tabular Data I/O in Julia
item.description: Importing tabular data into Julia can be done in (at least) three ways: reading a delimited file into an array, reading a delimited file into a DataFrame and accessing databases using ODBC.

item.title: Hadoop Streaming with Amazon Elastic MapReduce, Python and mrjob
item.description: In a previous rant about data science & innovation, I made reference to a problem I‚Äôm having at work where I wanted to classify roughly a quarter-billion URLs by predicted website content (without having to actually visit the website). A few colleagues have asked how you go about even starting to solve a problem like that, and the answer is massively parallel processing.

item.title: A Beginner’s Look at Julia
item.description: Over the past month or so, I‚Äôve been playing with a new scientific programming language called ‚ÄòJulia‚Äò, which aims to be a high-level language with performance approaching that of C. With that goal in mind, Julia could be a replacement for the ‚Äòmulti-language‚Äô problem of needing to move between R, Python, MATLAB, C, Fortran, Scala, etc. within a single scientific programming project.¬† Here are some observations that might be helpful for others looking to get started with Julia.

item.title: Getting Started Using Hadoop, Part 3: Loading Data
item.description: In part 2 of the ‚ÄúGetting Started Using Hadoop‚Äù series, I discussed how to build a Hadoop cluster on Amazon EC2 using Cloudera CDH. This post will cover how to get your data into the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) using the publicly available ‚ÄúAirline Dataset‚Äú. While there are multiple ways to upload data into HDFS, this post will only cover the easiest method, which is to use the Hue ‚ÄòFile Browser‚Äô interface.

item.title: Innovation Will Never Be At The Push Of A Button
item.description:
@randyzwitch @benjamingaines @usujason I am envisioning the data science equivalent of an autonomous vehicle pileup.

‚Äî Todd Belcher (@toddmetrics) May 16, 2013

item.title: Getting Started Using Hadoop, Part 2: Building a Cluster
item.description: In Part 1 of this series, I discussed some of the basic concepts around Hadoop, specifically when it‚Äôs appropriate to use Hadoop to solve your data engineering problems and the terminology of the Hadoop eco-system. This post will cover how to install your own Hadoop cluster on Amazon EC2 using Cloudera Manager.

item.title: Getting Started Using Hadoop, Part 1: Intro
item.description: For the last couple of days I‚Äôve been at the eMetrics conference in San Francisco. There were several panels that discussed big data, both from an engineering standpoint as well as how to adopt newer technologies from a business perspective.

item.title: Instructions for Installing & Using R on Amazon EC2
item.description: If you‚Äôre an R user, you‚Äôve surely heard all the hype around ‚Äòbig data‚Äô and how R is commonly used to analyze these volumes of data. One thing that‚Äôs often missing from the discussion is HOW to work around issues using big data and R, specifically how to deal with the fact that R stores all its objects in-memory.

item.title: Automated Re-Install of Packages for R 3.0
item.description: With the big release of R 3.0 today comes an unfortunate side effect of needing to re-install all of your packages. Luckily, R provides a pretty easy method of getting all of your packages into a list for automated re-install.¬† Here‚Äôs how to do it for OSX users with a default install to the Library:

item.title: The Fun of Error Trapping: R Package Edition
item.description: For the last month or so I‚Äôve been working on an R package to make accessing the Adobe (Omniture) Digital Marketing Suite Reporting API easier.¬† As part of this development effort, I‚Äôm at the point where I‚Äôm intentionally introducing errors into my function inputs, trying to guess some of the ways useRs might incorrectly input arguments into each function.¬† Imagine my surprise when I saw this:

item.title: (not provided): Using R and the Google Analytics API
item.description: (not provided) terms from Google average 35%-60% of all Google organic search terms

item.title: Video: SQL Queries in R using sqldf
item.description: This video covers how to run SQL queries using the ‚Äòsqldf‚Äô package within R. This sqldf tutorial was part of a Keystone Solutions podcast discussion about data science and what skills beginning analysts should be learning to improve their skill set.

item.title: Adding a ‘Back to Top’ Link on WordPress
item.description: In a previous post, I discussed how to remove ‚ÄúPowered By WordPress‚Äù from the footer of the Scrappy theme.¬† You might also want to add a ‚ÄúBack to Top‚Äù link in the footer, especially if your blog has a lot of vertical distance from the top to the bottom.¬† Here‚Äôs how to do it‚Ä¶

item.title: Video: Overlay Histogram in R (Normal, Density, Another Series)
item.description: This video explains how to overlay histogram plots in R for 3 common cases: overlaying a histogram with a normal curve, overlaying a histogram with a density curve, and overlaying a histogram with a second data series plotted on a secondary axis.

item.title: Video: R, RStudio, Rcmdr & rattle
item.description: I did a screencast for my co-workers to show how to get started with R, specifically what a base installation of R looks like, then showing how to improve your workflow using RStudio, Rcmdr or rattle.¬† The examples are somewhat pedestrian, but it gives a feel for what using R actually looks like.

item.title: Getting Started Using R, Part 2: Rcmdr
item.description: In my first post in this series, I discussed RStudio, an IDE that adds significant functionality and consistency to a basic installation of R.¬† In this post, I will discuss Rcmdr, a GUI that provides the ability to do basic business statistics without having to code in R.

item.title: Getting Started Using R, Part 1: RStudio
item.description: Despite my preference for SAS over R, there are some add-ons to ‚Äúbasic‚Äù R that I‚Äôve found that have made my learning process way easier.¬† While I‚Äôm still in my infancy in learning R, I feel like once I found these additional tools, my ability to use R to get work done improved significantly.

item.title: Learning R Has Really Made Me Appreciate SAS
item.description: For the past 18 months, it seems like all I‚Äôve heard about in the digital marketing industry is ‚Äúbig data‚Äù, and with that, mentions of using Hadoop and R to solve these sorts of problems.¬† Why are these tools the most often mentioned?¬† Because they are open source, i.e. free of charge!

item.title: Get Rich With Google AdSense And WordPress!
item.description: There are as many reasons to blog as there are people on Earth.¬† Whether it‚Äôs to use a blog as a personal diary, a means to share something you are passionate about (like cooking, as my wife does), a ‚Äúvoice‚Äù for your professional career or something else, eventually the question comes up:¬† should I try and earn advertising income from Google AdSense from my readership?

item.title: For Maximum User Understanding, Customize the SiteCatalyst Menu
item.description: Customizing anything is better than customizing nothing ‚Äì Jason Egan (@jasonegan)

item.title: Effect Of Modified Bounce Rate In Google Analytics
item.description: A few months back, Justin Cutroni posted on his blog some jQuery code that modifies how Google Analytics tracks content.¬† Specifically, the code snippet changes how bounce rate and time on site are calculated, creates a custom variable to classify whether visitors are ‚ÄúReaders‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúScanners‚Äù and adds some Google Analytics events to track how far down the page visitors are reading.

item.title: Adobe Discover 3: First Impressions
item.description: With yesterday‚Äôs code release, Omniture Adobe released version 3 of their ‚ÄúDiscover‚Äù tool, THE way to perform web analysis within the Adobe Digital Marketing Suite.¬† While SiteCatalyst has its place for basic reporting, to really dig deep into your data for actionable insights there‚Äôs no substitute to using Discover.

item.title: Removing ‘Powered by WordPress’ From Scrappy
item.description: My wife started a food blog this weekend and decided to use the ‚ÄúScrappy‚Äù WordPress theme by Caroline Moore.¬† But like all WordPress themes, there are a few customizations that are usually made to personalize the theme, the first of which is removing ‚ÄúPowered by WordPress‚Äù in the footer.

item.title: How To Install Optimizely on WordPress
item.description: If you‚Äôve spent any time working in digital marketing or analytics, you‚Äôre already familiar with the power of A/B testing.¬† A/B testing (and it‚Äôs more complicated brother multivariate testing) allows site owners to find out optimal combinations of site design and content for their visitors without having to directly ask/inconvenience the user.¬† All it takes to improve a website is forming a hypothesis of something that could work better, creating multiple versions of a page (or other content), setting up the experiment‚Ä¶and the money flows in faster than you can count it.¬† At least, that‚Äôs the hope!

item.title: Using Omniture SiteCatalyst Target Report To Calculate YOY growth
item.description: Of the hundreds of stock reports and capabilities present within Adobe (Omniture) SiteCatalyst, calculating year-over-year growth isn‚Äôt the easiest thing to do.¬† And while conversion reports (eVars) have the ‚ÄúCompare Dates‚Äù functionality within the calendar menu, we can‚Äôt quickly plot the difference between two time periods within a dashboard.¬† This is where the Omniture SiteCatalyst Target report comes in handy.

item.title: Claim Your Newest Klout Perk: An SEC Investigation!
item.description: “Ownership in startup companies for nothing…sign up today!”

item.title: 100 Miles For charity:water – 12/1 Update
item.description: Donations come in spurts, but the running continues!

item.title: 100 Miles For charity:water
item.description: In the past couple of weeks, I‚Äôve started a project through the Analysis Exchange working with Jason Thompson and charity:water.¬† If you‚Äôre not familiar with the Analysis Exchange, it‚Äôs a program where aspiring web analysts and grizzled veterans* volunteer to provide analytics services to charities.¬† Through the Analysis Exchange, charities are helped, students are mentored, and the World is a slightly better place than when the project was started.

item.title: Page Navigation For WordPress Twenty Eleven
item.description: By default, most WordPress themes (including Twenty Eleven) have relatively weak page-to-page navigation.¬† Users can improve content structure on their WordPress blogs by using categories, tags, and custom menus, but one navigation element that‚Äôs a bit more difficult to modify are the ‚ÄúNext Page/Previous Page‚Äù links.¬† These links are great if you want to move a page at a time, but if your blog has lots of pages, users won‚Äôt easily be able to navigate very deeply into your content.¬† That‚Äôs where a page navigation menu comes in handy.

item.title: iPhone 4S: A Worthy Upgrade Clouded By Activation Issues
item.description: When the iPhone 4S was announced on October 4th, there was much gnashing of teeth by Apple fanboys and stock market analysts about how this ‚Äúlackluster‚Äù iPhone refresh was going to allow competitors to overtake Apple. That without a re-designed case and bigger screen and more storage and‚Ä¶and‚Ä¶and. All of the rumors (and the subsequent disappointment) ignored one of the simple economic realities of the cell phone market:

item.title: Google Analytics SEO reports: Not Ready For Primetime?
item.description: On October 4th, Google¬†announced¬†that the Webmaster Tools/Google Analytics integration was now available to all users.¬†The three new reports (Queries, Landing Pages, and Geographical Summary) are intended to allow site owners and content creators to monitor how well their content is indexed in Google for their keywords of interest across time, all within¬†the Google Analytics interface. ¬†However, based on my preliminary research from the first few days of data, I have to question the current algorithm‚Äôs accuracy.

item.title: Installing Google Plus Button on WordPress
item.description: If you‚Äôve been anywhere on the internet in the past few months, you‚Äôve seen the +1 button from Google right next to Facebook, Twitter, StumbleUpon and other social media sharing buttons. ¬†It‚Äôs pretty clear that Google intends the ‚Äúplus one‚Äù to be THE most important form of approval on the ‚Äònet, integrating all those ‚Äúplusses‚Äù into search results as well as showing them within the Google+ Plus network.

item.title: Prevent Google Analytics From Tracking Logged-in Users
item.description: In a previous post, I discussed how it‚Äôs useful to have both WordPress Stats and Google Analytics installed on a WordPress blog; the former can be used as a quick dashboard to check in on the day‚Äôs traffic, and the latter can be used for more advanced analysis. ¬†But in order to keep our datasets comparable, we need to track users in a similar manner.

item.title: WordPress Stats or Google Analytics? Yes!
item.description: To understand the success of your blog content and site design, you need actionable data on your visitors and how they are interacting with your site.¬† Whether to use WordPress Stats or Google Analytics (or both) to obtain this data depends on your goals.

item.title: Twenty Eleven Child Theme: Custom Header
item.description: In a previous post about creating a child theme for Twenty-Eleven, we created a custom CSS file using the @import CSS rule.¬† Technically, the new CSS file is all that is needed to create a child theme in WordPress, but just changing the colors and font styles isn‚Äôt that much fun.¬† If it‚Äôs worth making your own WordPress child theme, it‚Äôs worth changing _everything‚Ä¶_starting with creating a custom header file.
